raw_text:
Ocean's Twelve raids box office
 
 Ocean's Twelve, the crime caper sequel starring George Clooney, Brad Pitt and Julia Roberts, has gone straight to number one in the US box office chart.
 
 It took $40.8m (£21m) in weekend ticket sales, according to studio estimates. The sequel follows the master criminals as they try to pull off three major heists across Europe. It knocked last week's number one, National Treasure, into third place. Wesley Snipes' Blade: Trinity was in second, taking $16.1m (£8.4m). Rounding out the top five was animated fable The Polar Express, starring Tom Hanks, and festive comedy Christmas with the Kranks.
 
 Ocean's Twelve box office triumph marks the fourth-biggest opening for a December release in the US, after the three films in the Lord of the Rings trilogy. The sequel narrowly beat its 2001 predecessor, Ocean's Eleven which took $38.1m (£19.8m) on its opening weekend and $184m (£95.8m) in total. A remake of the 1960s film, starring Frank Sinatra and the Rat Pack, Ocean's Eleven was directed by Oscar-winning director Steven Soderbergh. Soderbergh returns to direct the hit sequel which reunites Clooney, Pitt and Roberts with Matt Damon, Andy Garcia and Elliott Gould. Catherine Zeta-Jones joins the all-star cast. "It's just a fun, good holiday movie," said Dan Fellman, president of distribution at Warner Bros. However, US critics were less complimentary about the $110m (£57.2m) project, with the Los Angeles Times labelling it a "dispiriting vanity project". A milder review in the New York Times dubbed the sequel "unabashedly trivial".

The film follows master criminals as they attempt to pull off three heists across Europe.

Directed by Steven Soderbergh, it reunites the cast from Ocean's Eleven.
Critics were divided; some praised it as "fun" while others found it overly trivial.
opencoder:1.5b: "Ocean's Twelve marked the first-time opening of a new box office at number one.
It took studio estimates, about $40.8m (£21m) to produce, followed by three major heists across Europe which knocked it into third place.
The second film, Blade: Trinity, was also in the top five, but it earned less than $4.6m (£2.5m).
The Polar Express and Christmas with Kranks combined, earning about $8.1m (£4.7m) and a smaller amount in total.
The 2001 predecessor, Ocean's Eleven, brought in about $38.1m (£19.8m), while the remake added about $110m (£57.2m).
In closing, it was more than fun, but critics criticized its price tag as "dispiriting."
A more positive review in the New York Times was given as "unabashedly trivial."."
smollm:1.7b: Ocean's Twelve has gone straight to number one in the US box office chart, according to studio estimates.
It took $40.8 million (£21m) in weekend ticket sales, which is a significant amount considering it was released in December and had already sold out by the end of the month.
The sequel follows the master criminals as they try to pull off three major heists across Europe, knocking last week's number one, National Treasure, into second place.
Wesley Snipes' Blade: Trinity is in second place, taking $16.1 million (£8.4m).
Rounding out the top five is animated fable The Polar Express, starring Tom Hanks, and festive comedy Christmas with the Kranks.
deepseek-r1:1.5b: Ocean's Twelve has triumphantly charted to number one on US box office rolls with its crime drama sequel directed by Steven Soderbergh.
It garnered $40.8 million in weekend sales, outperforming the highly anticipated National Treasure film.
Key sequels like Rival Fright and The Polar Express solidified its position as a major hit.
The film features prominent stars including Wesley Snipes in Blade: Trinity.
Despite initial praise from critics, its modest budget and less-than-expected reception in the NY Times have drawn mixed reviews.
tinyllama:1.1b: In its first weekend of release, the Ocean's Twelvce sequel has taken the top spot in the US box office chart.
It earned $40.8m (£21m), surpassing last week's number one, National Treasure, which took $16.1m (£8.4m).
The third installment of the Ocean's trilogy starred George Clooney, Brad Pitt and Julia Roberts, as they attempt to pull off three major heists across Europe.
It was followed by animated fantasy comedy film Christmas with the Kraanks, starring Tom Hopper and Olivia Cooke, which made $13m (£7.6m).
The fourth largest opening for a December release in the US, it beat the 2001 predecessor, Ocean's Eleven, which took $38.1m (£19.8m) on its opening weekend and $184m (£95.8m) in total.
A remakes of the classic film, directed by Steven Soderbergh, starred Clooney, Pitt, and Roberts alongside Matt Damon and Andy Garcia, who also reprised his role as an FBI agent.
Critics were less than impressed, with The New York Times calling it a "dispirating vanity project" and the Los Angeles Times describing it as a "unabashingly triviaal".
tinydolphin:1.1b: Ocean's Twelve, starring George Clooney, Brad Pitt and Julia Roberts, has scored its best opening weekend box office since Ocean's Eleven.
The crime caper sequel has taken $40.8m (£21m) in ticket sales across the US, according to studio estimates.
This is the fourth-biggest opening for a December release in the US, after three films in the Lord of the Rings trilogy.
Ocean's Twelve stands as the third most successful film from the 2001 original, which had taken $38.1m (£19.8m) on its opening weekend and $184m (£95.8m) in total.
The remake of the 1960s film is directed by Steven Soderbergh, starring Clooney, Pitt, and Roberts alongside Matt Damon, Andy Garcia, and Ellen Page.
Ocean's Twelve has been produced by Warner Bros., with Fellman serving as president of distribution.
Despite mixed reviews from critics, the film received a solid reception, with many calling it a "dispirting vanity project."
However, some have praised its humor and the casting of Zeta-Jones in the lead role.

Critics were divided, with some praising it as a fun holiday movie while others criticized it as a dispiriting vanity project.
